awd_titl_txt: Catalyst design for (n,m)-targeted carbon nanotube syntheses
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have failed to fulfill long-held expectations of high-surface-area coupled with outstanding electronic properties.  This owes primarily to an inability to catalytically synthesize the nanotubes as single-walled entities in a patterned "chiral" (n,m)-structure; and is despite theoretical arguments by the principal investigator that such structures should be possible if the proper combination of catalyst, support and chemical vapor deposition conditions can be achieved.  Recently, experimental success in producing such chiral CNTs has been demonstrated.  The project will draw upon the experimental achievement to develop refined and expanded theoretical predictions that should guide further developments of catalytic chemical vapor deposition (CCVD) toward optimal catalytic materials and processing conditions.  The ability to produce single-wall carbon nanotubes of high purity at industrial scale could have profound effects on commercial applications of CNT technology, ideally with U.S. researchers leading the way.

The project will evolve a critical recent breakthrough in the PI's group revealing that the origin of CNT chirality can be described by a set of guidelines that will aid design of catalysts for (n,m)-targeted CNT synthesis. The researchers now clearly recognize that this complex phenomenon lies at the intersection of two large and mature fields: heterogeneous catalysis and crystal growth. Bringing together these paradigms from chemistry and materials science is expected to result in a transformative theoretical framework that should enable finding ways to engineer chiral selective CNT production, thus advancing a variety of long-awaited applications, all pending availability of single (n,m) type material. This will be achieved by a comprehensive atomistic investigation of structure and energetics of various metal-nanoparticle catalysts combined with state-of-the-art quantitative analysis of the thermodynamics and kinetics of ruling processes at the catalyst-CNT interface. To enable a higher probability of significantly new understanding, hypotheses based on such microscopic results will be validated through a continuing comparison with experimental data in the literature and through contacts with several experimental labs.  The cross-disciplinary nature of the project will provide educational opportunities to both graduate and undergraduate students in computational chemistry, molecular dynamics, and statistical physics.  Research results will be organized in a curated public materials property database.  The project will also involve outreach to Houston high school students through Rice University and close ties to the Houston Museum of Natural Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Catalytic growth of single-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs) is a complex phenomenon that lies at the intersection of two large and mature fields: heterogeneous catalysis and crystal growth. Bringing together these paradigms from chemistry and materials science is expected to result in a transformative theoretical framework that may enable finding ways to engineer chiral-selective CNT production, thus advancing a variety of long-awaited applications, all pending availability of pure material. Presently, one of the most challenging problems is the origin of chiral selectivity when using solid catalysts. Over the past several years the dominant explanation has been based on a simplistic "symmetry matching" scenario.

Our quantitative analysis of the CNT/catalyst system has lead to a few major findings that are expected to have a direct impact on the basic premises for modeling and understanding the catalytic CNT synthesis in general: 

  • Energetic preference toward a non-circular, "Janus", CNT/catalysts interface on solid catalysts. This zigzag || armchair "segregation" (as in Figure 1) has a dramatic effect on both nucleation probability and kinetics of growth. In contrast to previously proposed symmetry-matching between the conventional circular CNT edge and catalyst surface, we show that the synthesis of CNTs with high selectivity when using solid catalysts can be a result of a complex kinetics of growth.

  • This trend appears to be universal: we have demonstrated it for typical monometallic (Ni, Co), bimetallic (Co7W6), and metal carbide (WC) catalysts, using both an universal continuum model and first-principles, total-energy calculations based on density functional theory.

  • As a consequence of the discovered Janus-segregation trend, the underlying reduction in interface energies results in a substantial increase of the equilibrium nucleation probability of all chiral tubes. 

  • In collaboration with experiment, the resilience of the zeolite‐supported nanoparticles against encapsulation is revealed, presumably due to the through‐pore nature of the zeolite networks which makes it possible to continuously grow small‐diameter zigzag and near‐zigzag CNTs. The through‐pore‐supported catalyst particles, thus, leverage particle/support interactions to stay small and remain active during nucleation.

  • Obtaining single-chirality carbon nanotubes in catalytic synthesis can be achieved by an evolutionary selection mechanism: a local yet moving reaction zone (the gas feedstock or elevated temperature, as in Figure 2) can entice the tubes to follow, so that only the fastest survive. Reversing the reaction to dissolution would further eliminate the too fast-reactive types so that a desired chirality is singled out in production.

Advancing a variety of long-awaited applications are all pending availability of pure and especially pure-chirality CNT material. The industry has recognized the inability to manufacture large volumes of identical CNTs, as a major "hurdle" towards carbon nanotube based electronics: from CNT field-effect transistors to large integrated circuits and a complete CNT computer. In terms of energy efficiency, CNT-based components could offer an advantage of more than an order of magnitude compared to the Si-based technologies. Our findings already narrow the range of possible mechanisms for chiral selectivity (emphasizing the potential of kinetics-control mechanisms) and are likely to help achieve pure-CNT products thus benefiting various engineering fields as well as industry. This, as we believe, with further in-depth theory and simulation analyses, paralleled by hand in hand work with experimental labs, should revive the entire field of CNT research and revolutionize the long-anticipated variety of applications. 

The cross-disciplinary nature of the project, involving elements of computational chemistry, molecular dynamics, and statistical physics, has provided optimal ground for truly interdisciplinary training of students. The systematic computational/modeling approach has sampled a relatively large parameter space, an effort that has actively involved a few graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher. The developed computational/modeling framework has also been an excellent source of practical examples for a course that the PI is teaching at Rice (MSNE 433/533, "Computational materials modeling").
